title: CEOs Say: Fasten Your Seat Belts
subtitle: After a blockbuster 2021, business leaders brace for tougher times.

metadata.excerpt: ▸ AT THIS TIME LAST YEAR, the Fortune 500 CEOs we surveyed were breathing a collective sigh of relief as profits and revenues came roaring back from the ravages of the pandemic. This spring, that roar sounds uncomfortably loud, as companies cope with soaring inflation and the growing likelihood that sky-high prices and labor shortages will help tip the economy into recession. CEOs say they’re working hard on the labor side of that equation, scrambling to stem employee attrition by staying flexible about how and where people work. Climate change and geopolitical instability, meanwhile, loom ever larger, pressuring leaders to either speak up or hunker down.

components.text: CEOs Say: Fasten Your Seat Belts
After a blockbuster 2021, business leaders brace for tougher times.

<lede>AT THIS TIME LAST YEAR,</lede> the Fortune 500 CEOs we surveyed were breathing a collective sigh of relief as profits and revenues came roaring back from the ravages of the pandemic. This spring, that roar sounds uncomfortably loud, as companies cope with soaring inflation and the growing likelihood that sky-high prices and labor shortages will help tip the economy into recession. CEOs say they’re working hard on the labor side of that equation, scrambling to stem employee attrition by staying flexible about how and where people work. Climate change and geopolitical instability, meanwhile, loom ever larger, pressuring leaders to either speak up or hunker down.
<ledes>WHEN CEOs EXPECT THE NEXT RECESSION TO BEGIN</ledes>
Companies Experiencing High Rates of Attrition Among Employees
<ledes>WHAT CEOs SEE AS THE TOP THREATS TO THEIR BUSINESS</ledes>
<lede>INTENDED RETURN-TO-WORK POLICY FOR THE COMING YEAR</lede>
<ledes>SHOULD CEOs TAKE POSITIONS ON SOCIAL AND POLITICAL ISSUES?</ledes>
<lede>THE NEXT MOVE FOR COMPANIES INVOLVED WITH CHINA</lede>
<lede>COMPANIES’ RESPONSE TO RUSSIA’S INVASION OF UKRAINE</lede>
<lede>TOP RISKS IN THE TRANSITION TO A LOW-CARBON ECONOMY OVER THE NEXT DECADE*</lede>

poll conducted May 2–16
* question provided by Zurich North America insurance
